newsitem.title: CHINA: Shanghai copper ends up on short-covering.
newsitem.headline: Shanghai copper ends up on short-covering.

text.p: Shanghai copper futures ended up on short-covering triggered by last Friday's gains on the London Metal Exchange but it is likely to fall again in the short term, traders said.
The most active February 1997 contract ended at 18,910 yuan ($2,278) per tonne, rising 140 yuan. It opened at 18,850 yuan, hitting an intra-day high of 18,940 and a low of 18,730.
November rose 280 to 18,680 yuan, December 20 to 18,620, January 80 to 18,830, March 120 to 19,000 and April 80 to 19,100.
Combined volume fell to 65,400 tonnes from 129,530.
